column3: and submit such determinations to the council.

column1: Summary: Establishes the Delta Stewardship Council to advance the coequal goals of assuring a more reliable water supply for the State and protecting
column2: restoring and enhancing the Delta ecosystem and certain values of the Delta. Requires the Delta Independent Science Board to develop a scientific program relating to the management of the Delta. Requires such plan to provide for financing of all programs consistent with specified principles. Requires the council to impose an annual fee on persons diverting waters.

column1: Water Conservation: Urban and Agricultural Planning

Summary: Requires the State to achieve a 20% reduction in urban per capita water use by a specified date. Requires an incremental process towards such goal. Requires each urban retail water supplier to develop urban use targets and an interim urban water use target. Requires agricultural water suppliers to implement efficient water management practices.

Summary: Requires the state to achieve a specified reduction in urban per capita water use by a specified date. Requires the reduction by made using incremental progress towards this goal. Requires the urban water supplier to develop water use targets and an interim water use target. Requires agricultural water suppliers to prepare
column3: and implement efficient water management plans and practices within a specified time frame. Eliminates state water grants and loans for non-compliant agricultural water suppliers. Statewide water conservation planning.

Summary: Requires a manufacturer of a compostable plastic bag to ensure that the bag is readily and easily identifiable from other plastic bags. Defines readily and easily identifiable to include labeling with an approved certification logo. Subject manufacturers and suppliers to auditing by the Integrated Waste Management Board.

Summary: Requires an urban water supplier to develop and implement a water use efficiency and efficient water resources management plan to reduce residential potable water use in a specified manner or achieve extraordinary water use efficiency. Requires the supplier or regional water management group to report its related progress. Enacts the Comprehensive Urban Water Efficiency Act. Requires the convening of a task force to develop best management practices for commercial and industrial uses to achieve reductions. Relates to efficiency and conservation (including rainwater harvesting).

Summary: Creates the Product Stewardship Act of 2009 and requires the Integrated Waste Management Board to administer the program. Provides environmentally sound product stewardship protocols that encourage producers to research alternatives during the product design and packaging phases to foster cradle-to-cradle producer responsibility and reduce the end-of-life environmental impacts of products. Creates the Extended Producer Responsibility Penalty Subaccount. Requires a recycling market development zone (RMDZ)
column3: technical assistance
column4: and free product marketing to businesses that use materials from the waste stream to manufacture their products
column5: to retain that designation for a certain number of years or until the local governing body repeals the designation. Contains a legislative finding and declaration that cities and counties are encouraged to propose RMDZs to stimulate economic development and create green jobs. (electronic waste) (plastic bottles) (hazardous waste)

column4: and management. Promotes rainwater harvesting.

Summary: Amends the Water Use Act of 1983. Provides that a high-capacity well is a well located on a parcel of property where the rate or capacity of water withdrawals of all wells on the property is in excess of 70 gallons per minute or 100
column2: 000 gallons during any 24-hour period. Provides that a high-capacity surface water intake is a surface water intake located on a parcel of property where the rate or capacity of water withdrawals is the same. Provides related definitions. Relates to irrigation withdrawals. Water quantity.

Summary: Relates to an excise on plastic carryout bags in supermarkets. Every supermarket shall pay to the commissioner an excise equal to 5 cents per plastic carryout bag provided to customers during the tax year. No customer shall pay an excise on: (1) the customer's own plastic or compostable plastic bag that the customer brought into the supermarket and uses to carry purchased items from the supermarket
column3: (3) any bag if the customer requests that plastic bags not be used
column4: (4) any compostable plastic bag provided to the customer by a supermarket
column5: or (5) any reusable bag the customer uses to carry purchased items out of the supermarket.
